title: Fed macro live, 21st March, 2018
openingHTML: Live Fed and markets commentary from Alphaville.
bodyHTML:
6:14 pm
AS6:14pm

Hi folks

AS6:15pm

Getting an early start to today's macro live, in part because markets seem utterly bored by this statement and I'm not sure why

MCK6:16pm

Welcome!

6:16 pm
AS6:17pm

As Matt points out the central tendency for 2020 went up by 50bps

AS6:17pm

and yet 10 year yields are up....

AS6:17pm

2bps

6:17 pm
MCK6:17pm

That is not unreasonable!

MCK6:17pm

The "longer-run" estimate of the Fed policy rate didn't move much

AS6:18pm

definitely not unreasonable, just.... boring

6:18 pm
MCK6:18pm

The new dots are showing a steeper tightening path, but the apparent implication is that this will get paid back later.

AS6:18pm

BUT we do have the presser coming up

MCK6:18pm

After all, the longer-run growth and inflation outlook is basically the same

6:18 pm
MCK6:19pm

Still, it does marginally increase the odds the Fed will be trying to deliberately slow the economy in 2020...

AS6:19pm

right as a decent amount of corporate debt comes up for refunding! how fun!

AS6:20pm

hey matt, remember the good old days

6:19 pm
MCK6:20pm

Oh and as we have an election

AS6:20pm

of Yellen's first press conference

MCK6:20pm

More or less? Anything you have in mind in particular?

6:21 pm
AS6:21pm

When she said they would wait "something on the order of around six months" before raising rates after QE ended

AS6:21pm

and everyone freaked out (by everyone I mean markets, mostly)

wilburkong Well, getting hawkish with a belief that the leveraged economy is robust and strong is a mistake. The withdrawal syndrome of cheap money will manifest in shift in expectations and risk profile which ultimately will derail the economy.. Globally......China have no chance in a soft landing deleveraging.
AS6:22pm

I will be watching for similar situations at Powell's presser today

6:21 pm
MCK6:22pm

ah right

bztrader EMs welcomed this but yeah it was utterly boring
AS6:22pm

hi wilburkong! you get our first prize

OnYourRight Evening all
AS6:22pm

for commenting first (this prize is #respec)

6:22 pm
MCK6:22pm

They stopped buying assets in October 2014. Then they started raising rates in December 2015. So 6 months was off but probably would have been accurate if not for all the fun in China/commods/credit that happened in between.

MCK6:23pm

Hello rabble!

AS6:23pm

Appears that our moderators might once again be less than speedy, apologies if your comments get stuck

6:24 pm
AS6:24pm

Anything catch your eye in the language of the statement Matt?

MCK6:25pm

The WSJ tracks changes, and you can see for yourself what's different. The answer is: not much

MCK6:25pm

https://projects.w...ent-tracker-embed/

6:25 pm
AS6:25pm

IIRC the inflation language might match up with the Verizon effect rolling off, right?

MCK6:26pm

For those who haven't seen, here are the projection tables

MCK6:26pm

https://www.federa...ojtabl20180321.pdf

6:26 pm
AS6:26pm

(when I grow up I would like to get a reputation for singlehandedly suppressing inflation figures a la Verizon)

MCK6:28pm

Embarassed smile

AS6:28pm

Matt I think we should speculate about your OIS discovery for the next three minutes

6:28 pm
AS6:28pm

that could be... what, hedging?

NJB We're gonna get a slight overshoot?
MCK6:29pm

Alex is referring to this post

NJB (According to the median projection, whomever that synthetic person is)
MCK6:30pm

https://ftalphavil...aps-on-february-5/

bztrader Why has the statement replaced "Chairman" with "Chair"?
6:30 pm
AS6:30pm

NJB asks if we're going to get a slight overshoot

AS6:31pm

which I'm guessing means from the terminal rate

MCK6:31pm

Powell getting to it:

CThwaites Here are the Dec and Mar dot plots together https://twitter.com/cthwaites1/status/976525656522543104
6:31 pm
AS6:31pm

agree it's notable that the 2020 rate is above the long-term rate -- along the lines of what Matt said about slowing the economy

AS6:32pm

I do think we have the Fed kinda calling the top in 2020

MCK6:32pm

You can watch the livestream here https://www.federalreserve.gov/

6:32 pm
AS6:32pm

thx CThwaites

MCK6:33pm

Pure style point, but Powell speaks much faster than Yellen.

OnYourRight For what it's worth........ Trump to announce anti China tariffs tomorrow.
MCK6:34pm

@OnYourRight I suspect someone will ask about that

OnYourRight @MCK Nervous?!?!?
celebrity gossip ant or Dec?
6:35 pm
MCK6:35pm

Continues Yellen's line that the Fed needs to tighten gradually to prevent worse outcome of tightening rapidly

AS6:37pm

balance sheet reduction "proceeding smoothly" he says

MCK6:37pm

Powell also reiterating that the short-rate is the primary policy tool but that they always retain flexibility to adjust according to economic conditions

6:37 pm
MCK6:38pm

First question is about the disconnect between inflation outlook and growth/unemployment outlook

MCK6:38pm

Powell responding that inflation not actually driven by unemployment

MCK6:40pm

Now Timaraos is asking about how symmetric the Fed is willing to be on inflation and whether they would want to have any catchup inflation to make up for past six years

6:41 pm
MCK6:42pm

Powell says they will be symmetric but doesn't want to get too specific

MCK6:42pm

Now Powell is saying the median gets too much attention relative to the whole distribution

Ken M It did not take long for them to ask a question meant to draw him out politically.
MCK6:42pm

He also notes that the projections are not a decision by the Fed, but a collection of individual opinions

CThwaites Q: Who's the 4.8% dot in 2020?
6:44 pm
MCK6:44pm

@CThwaites that's a good question. Could be Mester?

AS6:45pm

The 2-year Treasury yield is down now

wilburkong why do i get the feeling all the questions to Powell are full of traps
MCK6:45pm

Our man Sam Fleming now asking about whether "headwinds turning into tailwinds" will affect level of "neutral" short rates

/B Flemming wastes some vital global time with a pointless chaser question
6:45 pm
AS6:45pm

also whether they're going to have press conferences more often

AS6:46pm

was just chatting with a friend of Alphaville about the Fed statement -- he sees the decline in the 2-year yield as a sign that the equity market could get a little rattled by the rise in the medium-term dots

AS6:47pm

(of course now that I've said that stocks will start rallying or something)

6:47 pm
MCK6:47pm

How has 5yr yield moved?

AS6:47pm

5-year through 30-year are all up

MCK6:47pm

China tariffs question!

6:47 pm
AS6:47pm

2-year is... down? even though the actual two-year dots were.... higher?

MCK6:48pm

"A number of participants at this meeting brought up the issue of tariffs"

MCK6:48pm

"There is no question that trade policy will have an impact on the current outlook"

OnYourRight Is that code for "We're ignoring Trump"
6:49 pm
MCK6:49pm

Correction: no one thought it would affect current outlook but it would affect future outlook

MCK6:49pm

(sorry)

AS6:51pm

Looks like the 2s-30s steepened a lot after the announcement

6:51 pm
MCK6:51pm

"We made one decision at this meeting and that was to raise the target range by 25 basis points"

AS6:51pm

The stock market is down now

AS6:51pm

(a little)

6:51 pm
MCK6:52pm

That's Powell's response to questions about the projected rate path

MCK6:52pm

Next question on what would have to happen for trade policy to affect the outlook

AS6:53pm

So there's a steepener trade on and stocks are down

6:54 pm
AS6:54pm

Which now has me wondering if the market sees a chance that the Fed will let inflation pick up

MCK6:54pm

Alex that seems consistent with a hawkish interpretation

MCK6:54pm

Oh yes, or that

6:55 pm
MCK6:55pm

Next question is about 2020 policy forecast above "longer-run"

AS6:55pm

(if the view was that they'd be more hawkish we'd be seeing a flattener I think)

MCK6:55pm

Powell characterizes 2020 as "modestly restrictive"

6:56 pm
MCK6:56pm

And also says you should ignore forecasts for 2020

MCK6:57pm

Alex you're right that's interesting. As the one of us near a terminal, could you check how breakevens are doing?

AS6:59pm

You read my mind, was just checking

6:59 pm
MCK6:59pm

Powell seems to have been slightly rattled by the question about interest on excess reserves as a subsidy for banks

AS7:00pm

Breakevens are pretty much all higher for the day, but it wasn't an obvious response to the Fed statement

MCK7:00pm

His answer was that the Fed essentially pays a market rate and that the Fed's assets yield a lot more

7:00 pm
AS7:00pm

Though the 10-year breakeven rate temporarily rose a few bps after the statement

MCK7:01pm

How does that compare to the steepening you mentioned?

AS7:02pm

the steepening in the 2s-30s was right after the statement, looks like

7:02 pm
AS7:03pm

by 4 to 5 bps (to ~82bps)

AS7:03pm

Powell also mentioned nonfinancial corp leverage: "You do see relatively elevated levels of borrowing but nothing that suggests serious risks"

AS7:05pm

They're talking regs now -- not clear whether they'll decide to extend their reach if Congress rolls back some regs

7:07 pm
MCK7:07pm

"I've spent many years working with companies and the cost of capital is one of many factors" affecting investment decisions

MCK7:08pm

That was in response to question about "supply-side" impact of tax changes

AS7:08pm

(stock market's basically flat again)

7:09 pm
AS7:09pm

(my guess: any human equity traders who still work in Manhattan saw that the statement didn't have any big surprises and then ran to catch the train to Long Island before LIRR shuts down)

AS7:10pm

(for London rabble members who aren't on twitter or any method of transatlantic communication -- it's snowing here)

Ken M I wonder if the volatility since the first week of Feb has just led to people moving their stops out.
AS7:11pm

(a lot.)

/B banks take deposits then lend them? https://bankunderground.co.uk/2015/06/30/banks-are-not-intermediaries-of-loanable-funds-and-why-this-matters/
7:11 pm
AS7:12pm

Powell talks about wages a bit, says he's been surprised about the lack of wage growth in the US

MCK7:12pm

French journalist just asked about implication of being "restrictive" during 2020 election cycle. Powell says don't worry about it.

CThwaites "...LIRR" still they dumped REITs which has underperformed int GTs (ITE) post announcement
AS7:13pm

"It's true that rates are higher than they've been in 10 years, but it's a healthier economy than its' been in 10 years" - Powell

7:13 pm
MCK7:13pm

Myles Udland just asked about whether the Fed would tolerate an inverted yield curve. Powell says "that's an interesting question"

OnYourRight Thanks gents.... I'm off to use my bicycle lights for possibly my last dark commute home this winter!
MCK7:14pm

And that's it

AS7:14pm

REITs look like they've rebounded a bit since then CThwaites

7:14 pm
AS7:15pm

safe travels OnYourRight!

MCK7:15pm

Ok, summary thoughts?

AS7:15pm

REITs now close to pre-Fed levels, looks like

7:15 pm
AS7:16pm

I'm intrigued by the steepening of the curve, but not entirely sure what to make of it considering the lack of confirmation from the TIPS market

AS7:17pm

also wondering if Jerome Powell hired a voice coach so he would sound as pleasant and calm as possible in the first go-round

AS7:17pm

How about you Matt?

7:19 pm
MCK7:19pm

Powell expressed many of the same basic views as Janet Yellen but did so in a much more direct style, particularly the way he tried to shoot down questions he didn't like (trade, the forecasts, etc). The main substantive difference I picked up was his view on employment and how it flowed through to inflation.

AS7:19pm

interesting -- just less certainty about the relationship, or...?

MCK7:20pm

Yellen has always been a believer that a strong labor market will cause inflation to acclerate and a weak jobs market will cause it to slow down. Powell seems less convinced of that, noting how much better the jobs market has gotten without any inflation accleration.

7:20 pm
MCK7:20pm

He also seemed to say that the real sign of the job market's health was the rate of wage growth rather than anything else such as the unemployment rate.

AS7:21pm

which could imply a more dovish view than some people thought

AS7:21pm

So there we have it: A Phillips curve sceptic and a yield-curve puzzle

7:21 pm
AS7:21pm

Thanks to everyone who stopped by

MCK7:23pm

The interesting thing about the yield curve is that his answer seemed to imply the curve's predictive power comes from how it connects inflation to the Fed's reaction function, which is he said you shouldn't worry about it inverting if inflation is in check. We'll have to see!

MCK7:23pm

Good luck out there!

7:23 pm
AS7:24pm

Stay warm folks!
subheading: Live Fed and markets commentary from Alphaville.
standfirst: Live Fed and markets commentary from Alphaville.
